Third, the primary mechanism by which CCT is injected into the culture is not via academicians or even via popularizers like Robin DiAngelo and Ibram X. Kendi. Certainly, these best-selling authors have had an outsized impact on our culture. However, it’s unlikely that the average person on the street has read the works of any CCT-influenced scholar. Your coworker likely didn’t learn about white fragility by reading DiAngelo. He learned about it from watching an episode of MTV’s Decoded or listening to NPR’s Code Switch. Your teenage daughter didn’t learn about gender performativity by reading Judith Butler.

Marx believed that history unfolds as a series of struggles between opposing social groups, one of whom controls the “means of production.” Historical events and technological progress have led various economic systems to evolve, but always in a way that reproduces the stratification of society into the ruling class (those who own/control the means of production) and the working class. Marx theorized that capitalism itself was a temporary stage in social development that would eventually give rise to communism, after workers finally took control of the means of production and ushered in a classless utopia.

First, they reaffirmed Marx’s commitment to “liberation” and “emancipation” from oppressive social conditions.27 Second, they believed this goal was intimately linked to a perpetual critique of the status quo and with skepticism toward universal prescriptions and solutions. Third, they expanded Marx’s understanding of oppression significantly, recognizing that it could not be reduced to or traced back to economic arrangements. They critiqued not just various modes of production, but the “culture industry,” mass media, conformity, and other mechanisms by which modern nations limited human potential. Finally, like Marx and later theorists, many of the members of the Frankfurt School saw the destruction of the nuclear family and the eradication of traditional sexual morality as crucial to human liberation. In particular, Marcuse’s Eros and Civilization announced that “the only way for human beings to escape the one-dimensionality of advanced industrial society is to rebel against ‘technological rationality’ (i.e., the repressive values of capitalist morality), and to liberate our erotic side, our sensuous instincts.”

highlights.content: Marcuse’s key contribution to Marxism was his incorporation of Freudian psychoanalytical themes into a revolutionary program. He expanded the base for social revolution to include not only oppressed workers (an economic factor), but also those considered to be sexual or social deviants no matter what their economic class (a cultural factor), and those in minority groups (a racial factor). Thus, he called for homosexuals, lesbians, bisexuals, and those in other nontraditional sexual categories to join the revolution against the capitalist-traditional-family status quo. In Eros and Civilization: A Philosophical Inquiry into Freud, a 1959 bestseller, he writes that the body can be freed from monogamous constraints to find full erotic experience.39 Marcuse called for a “polymorphous” sexuality—one not limited by bourgeoise traditions of repression. For Marcuse, “a one-dimensional man” is anesthetized by material comforts and the blandishments of technological society. He must be roused from his capitalist torpor in order to discern his underlying discontent. Marcuse strained to explain Marx’s failed prophecy that the struggle between the bourgeois and proletariat would lead to revolution by claiming that “technological rationality” had somehow tamed the workers to make an unacknowledged pact with the owners. Now Marcuse would rip open the wound and reveal the disease.

author: Michael Walsh

highlights.content: The Frankfurt School sucker punched American culture right in its weak solar plexus.

Few of these ideas have proven more pernicious than those of the so-called Frankfurt School and its reactionary philosophy of “critical theory.” At once overly intellectualized and emotionally juvenile, Critical Theory—like Pandora’s Box—released a horde of demons into the American psyche. When everything could be questioned, nothing could be real, and the muscular, confident empiricism that had just won the war gave way, in less than a generation, to a fashionable Central European nihilism that was celebrated on college campuses across the United States. Seizing the high ground of academe and the arts, the new nihilists set about dissolving the bedrock of the country, from patriotism to marriage to the family to military service.
